content: The "Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act" or the "TEAM Act" defines terms like "Administration" and "small business concern" as per the Small Business Act. It also establishes the Office of Entrepreneurial Education. The Small Business Act is amended to include the creation of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education. The Small Business Act is amended to establish the Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Administration. This office will provide innovative entrepreneurial information, education, and resources to support prospective entrepreneurs and successful small businesses. The Director of the Office reports to the Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development and is responsible for developing and delivering these services. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education manages online courses, publications, and resources for entrepreneurs and small businesses, as well as youth entrepreneurship programs. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education oversees youth entrepreneurship programs, online resources, and partnerships with entrepreneurial development service providers and private sector partners. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education aims to support entrepreneurs by providing educational materials on money management and financial literacy, as well as offering assistance to individuals and foreign dignitaries interested in small business concerns. Additionally, they oversee a National Primary and Secondary School Entrepreneurial Education Program. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education supports entrepreneurs with educational materials on money management and financial literacy. They also offer assistance to individuals and foreign dignitaries interested in small business concerns. Additionally, they oversee a National Primary and Secondary School Entrepreneurial Education Program that provides grants to nonprofit organizations. The Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development will establish a program to provide grants to nonprofit organizations for technical assistance in developing entrepreneurship curricula and mentoring programs for primary and secondary schools. The Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development will provide grants to nonprofit organizations for curricula and mentoring programs promoting entrepreneurship in schools. Nonprofit organizations must submit an application outlining project goals, partners involved, and other relevant information. Nonprofit organizations receiving grants must submit a report within 1 year detailing individuals assisted and jobs created or saved. Nonprofit organizations receiving grants must submit a report within 1 year detailing individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and any other required information. Authorization of appropriations is set at $3,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2013 to 2015. Authorization of appropriations is set at $3,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2013 to 2015 to carry out entrepreneurial education programs. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education must submit a report on best practices within 180 days of the Act's enactment to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business. Entrepreneurial Education will provide a report to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business detailing best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs in the United States, including exemplary national, regional, state, and local programs. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education will report on exemplary programs at national, regional, state, and local levels, as well as summarize entrepreneurial education programs by the Federal Government, State and local governments, and nonprofit organizations and private sector groups. SEC. 4. MASTER OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION SCHOLARSHIP PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator may award up to 100 scholarships of $1,500 each to students pursuing a Masters of Business Administration degree. Recipients must provide free assistance to small businesses and entrepreneurs for 1 or 2 weeks. The Administrator awards scholarships to MBA students who must provide free assistance to small businesses and entrepreneurs for 1 or 2 weeks. At least 50% of the recipients must be students at institutions with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. The Administrator awards scholarships to MBA students who provide free assistance to small businesses and entrepreneurs for 1 or 2 weeks. The activities support various small business concerns and entrepreneurial projects, including investigator-led, interdisciplinary, and multi-institutional projects. Each student receiving a scholarship must be at an institution with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. The scholarships awarded to MBA students support small businesses and entrepreneurs through various projects, including investigator-led, interdisciplinary, and multi-institutional projects. Each student receiving a scholarship must have a mentor to help relate their academic studies to the project assistance provided. The agreement under paragraph (1) requires data collection from students receiving scholarships and small businesses/entrepreneurs receiving assistance. They must provide information on the use and results of the assistance and employment status for 3 years after the student's expected graduation date. Failure to comply with the agreement may result in consequences for the student. The agreement requires data collection from scholarship recipients and small businesses/entrepreneurs. They must provide information on the use of assistance and employment status for 3 years after graduation. Failure to comply may result in the scholarship being treated as a loan and subject to repayment with interest. The Administrator may award scholarships that could be treated as loans under the Higher Education Act, with repayment terms specified by the Administrator. $200,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2013-2015. The scholarship program ends after September 30, 2015. SEC. 5. REGIONAL ENTREPRENEURIAL COMPETITIONS. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Regional offices will identify issues and sponsor competitions among local small businesses and inventors. The program will sponsor a regional competition for small businesses, inventors, and entrepreneurs to address a prominent public-private issue in the region. Outreach will be conducted to universities, colleges, business communities, and nonprofit organizations to promote the competition and request research proposals. The program will conduct outreach to universities, colleges, business communities, industry leaders, and nonprofit organizations to promote a regional competition for small businesses, inventors, and entrepreneurs. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurship Education will select the top 3 research or business plans addressing the identified issue, and submit a report to the Administrator. The Administrator will organize a national conference for presenting selected research and business plans by regional administrators. The Administrator will designate 11 employees to serve on a panel that selects the best research and business plans from each region addressing specific issues. The Administrator will select 1 research and business plan from each region that best addresses specific issues, with 11 employees serving on the panel. The Administrator will award a $50,000 grant to individuals or groups with selected plans. Recipients must submit a report on grant usage within a year. The recipient of a $50,000 grant must submit a report on grant usage within a year. $750,000 is authorized for the Administrator to carry out this section. The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommendations for legislation to forgive student loans and defer loan repayments to support youth entrepreneurship by providing capital for business formation.
